TRADE UNIONS (AMENDMENT) BILL
First Reading


    Mr Speaker: Will the Minister please signify the recommendation of His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before he introduces the Trade Unions (Amendment) Bill?

    The Minister for Labour (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): I so signify, Sir. Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled, "An Ordinance to amend the Trade Unions Ordinance (Chapter 154 of the Revised Edition)".

    Bill read the First time.
Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

Column: 813



    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Now, Sir, I lay on the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in respect of the Trade Unions (Amendment) Bill.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Are copies of the Bill available for the use of Members?

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Yes.

    Copies of the Bill handed in to the Clerk and distributed to hon. Members.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time." I have His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation that this Bill be proceeded with. I also have a Certificate of Urgency by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara to proceed with the Bill through all its stages under Standing Order No. 81.

    In my statement at the sitting of the Assembly on 11th December, 1963, I have already touched on the matter of the setting up of a one-man Commission of Inquiry to look into and examine the financial transactions of three deregistered trade unions. I have already recounted to hon. Members how unscrupulous and mercenary anti-national leaders of unions could usurp the funds of the workers towards purposes inconsistent with the objects and rules of the unions to the detriment of the unions and danger to the State. In order that the interests of the workers may be safeguarded, the Government now consider it necessary that the Bill before the House should be taken through all its stages and passed on a Certificate of Urgency. As I have stated previously, the reason for bringing in the Bill on a Certificate of Urgency is obvious. The Assembly will be adjourning shortly and it is necessary that the Bill be passed in order that there will be effective legislation to prevent trade union funds from being frittered away illegally and dishonestly. The Government at present have no power to deal with the funds of unions which are deregistered or are being given notices to show cause why they should not be deregistered.

    The Trade Unions Ordinance which was passed in 1940 did not foresee that

Column: 814

there are so-called trade union leaders here in Singapore capable of taking away large amounts of money of the workers for purposes known only to their secret masters. As a result of this, once a union is deregistered, the money of the union is left at the mercy of the union leaders. Amongst themselves they can do anything they like with the money. Although union rules require them to distribute the money to the general members, in most cases this is never done. In fact, in the case of the Singapore General Employees' Union, the Secretary-General, when called upon by the police to explain why certain amounts of money were expended, disappeared with some union minute books. So you can see how dangerous it is to leave large amounts of money in the hands of union officials who are capable of going underground at any moment. They do not have the workers' interests at heart. The workers' money is not used to further the interests of the workers. It is being used for some inexplicable purpose.

    On 3rd September, 1963, the Yang di-Pertuan Negara issued a writ to dissolve the previous Assembly and ordered fresh elections. Everyone knew that elections were coming and elections cost money. And it was exactly on this day, the 3rd of September, that leaders of the three unions, viz, the Singapore General Employees' Union, the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union, and the Singapore Bus Workers' Union decided to withdraw large amounts of money from their banks. I can leave it to you to draw your own conclusion as to what they intend to use this money for. The Government cannot afford to be complacent in this matter. If we are to protect the interests of the workers, I am sure hon. Members will agree that stringent and urgent action must be taken to deal with the situation.

    At present the Trade Unions Ordinance does not empower the Minister or the Registrar of Trade Unions to freeze the bank accounts of any trade union if information is received that the union

Column: 815

intends to utilise its funds for any purpose contrary to the provisions of the Ordinance or the rules of the union itself. While the Registrar has power to apply to the Court for an injunction to restrain any trade union from unlawful expenditure of its funds, this process in law, however, is not practicable especially when the matter has to be dealt with on an immediate basis. Because the present Ordinance does not provide the necessary powers, the Registrar of Trade Unions could only advise banks holding the accounts of unions to suspend payment of any cheques drawn on them. Although in the case of the three deregistered S.A.T.U. unions the banks co-operated with the Government, they were in a difficult position as the Government's request had no statutory backing. This being so, the banks would therefore be liable for damages if they were sued by their clients. As Government had perforce to freeze the funds of these unions, it was necessary, therefore, for the Government to give a categorical assurance that it would indemnify any legal costs arising from any proceedings as a result of their failing to honour the unions' cheques.

    Despite action taken by the Registrar to request the banks to withhold withdrawals which might be initiated by these three S.A.T.U. unions, two of the unions, however, were able to withdraw about $30,000 from their accounts in a number of banks before the banks could receive Government's indemnification assurance. The new section 15A provided in clause 2 of the Bill will now enable the Minister, where he is satisfied that the funds of any unions may be misused, to order any bank in Singapore not to pay any money or to cash any cheques of the unions for a period not exceeding three months. Non-compliance with this order will make the manager of the bank liable to punishment as set out in subsection (3) of section 15A. Subsection (2) will, of course, absolve the bank of any liability arising from compliance with the order

Column: 816

of the Minister. Clause 3 of the Bill amends section 18 of the Ordinance, and this amendment is necessary having regard to the new section 18A provided under clause 4. The new section 18A in clause 4 of the Bill will obviate any undue delay in the winding up and disposal of funds of unions which have been dissolved on the grounds that they have not applied for registration or where their registration has been refused, withdrawn or cancelled. There are many instances where unions that have been dissolved have still to wind up and dispose of their funds. A glaring instance is that of the Singapore Factory and Shop Workers' Union, which was deregistered in 1957, and to date it has still to wind up and dispose of its funds. Hon. Members will, therefore, see that the powers sought in the new section 18A are necessary. Once a trade union is dissolved, the assets of the union will vest immediately in the Official Assignee in Bankruptcy so that he can proceed to wind up the affairs of the union. Any surplus assets after providing for all debts and liabilities will, if the Minister directs, be paid into the Consolidated Fund; or where no such direction is made, will be disposed of as provided in the rules of the trade union in question. It is very necessary that the assets of the dissolved trade union should vest in the Official Assignee in Bankruptcy to prevent officials of the union from making any withdrawals on the accounts of the union held by any bank between the period when notice has been given by the Registrar of Trade Unions to the union of the intention to dissolve such union, and the actual date of dissolution if dissolution takes place.

    I have already recounted instances of such irresponsible withdrawals in my statement of 11th December. This will make very interesting hearing when the Commission of Inquiry sits to look into the matter.

    The new section 18B gives retrospective effect to the Bill so that the unions deregistered or cancelled prior to the date of 11th December, 1963, can be

Column: 817

dealt with in the same way. I would like, therefore, to commend this Bill to the House so that it can be taken through all its stages and passed at today's sitting. I do not propose to overemphasise how essential it is for Government to be given the powers sought in the Bill. Any person having the interest of the workers and the protection of the funds which rightfully belong to the workers will undoubtedly support the enabling measures that will be vested in Government by the amendments proposed in the Bill.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the fact that the P.A.P. Government have now tabled this Trade Unions (Amendment) Bill shows that they are taking further action against the workers. This will thus deal a blow to the workers who do not allow themselves to be controlled by the P.A.P. The P.A.P. have always boasted in the past that it is their intention to have an open argument. But this so-called open argument and competition has not been used in the true sense. As a result of their insincerity in the so-called open argument and competition, the Government have taken action to ban some trade unions and have arrested their leaders. Some of the workers and their leaders who went on strike were assaulted. Apart from this, the P.A.P. Government have also made use of the State machinery to break up the non-P.A.P. union strikes. This can be seen from their repressive actions in the past. Seven unions were dissolved. The application for registration by S.A.T.U. was also turned down. The Naval Base Workers' Union strike, which lasted about thirty days, was a legitimate strike. But it was broken up by the P.A.P. by illegal means and despicable methods.

    In spite of all these actions, the P.A.P. have discovered that they have not sufficient powers to deal with the workers

Column: 818

whose only wish is to struggle for a better life and improve their working conditions, which are their legitimate rights. In spite of all these actions, the workers are as united as ever. They are as adamant as ever. This fact has worried the P.A.P. very much. That is why the P.A.P. are now taking a step further. They are abusing the legal and State machinery by tabling this Bill, which is an attempt to gain control over the unions' funds. In other words, unions which do not support the P.A.P. can be controlled by the P.A.P. There are provisions in this Trade Unions (Amendment) Bill which empower the Minister to freeze a union's funds deposited in a bank for a period of three months when the Minister is satisfied that the funds may be misused. We know that workers have contributed to the trade unions' funds by way of monthly subscriptions. Therefore, the disposal of the funds should be decided by the workers themselves and not by the Minister and the P.A.P. The funds should not be interfered with. The trade union officials have been elected by the workers themselves. They have been entrusted to administer the funds. They are held responsible to the workers and members of the unions. So long as the workers of the unions agree to the action taken by their elected officials, and so long as the administration of the unions' funds is not inconsistent with the rules and regulations of the unions, the Minister should not be given any right to interfere with such administration of the unions' funds. In fact, nobody should be allowed to interfere with them.

    The phrase "satisfied that it is likely that the funds of the union may be misused", is actually typical of Fascist methods. It seems that only the Minister is able to decide whether a union's funds are being used in the right and proper manner. We know that if the Minister is given this power, then he may make use of this power as an excuse to take action against the union which refuses to be under the control of the P.A.P. Trade union funds come from the workers themselves. They subscribe to these funds in their own interest and for union activities. They can be considered as the capital of the workers

Column: 819

for their union activities. If their funds can be frozen at the whims and fancies of the Minister, then the workers will face great difficulties in carrying out their activities. They will have no financial backing if they wish to increase their wages through legitimate methods. For example, if members of a union decide to stage a strike or take any other industrial action, which is their weapon, to fight for better working conditions, then the Minister may, if he so desires, break up this impending strike or even if a strike is on. He does this by exerting pressure on the bank to freeze the funds of the union in question. If a union is not able to withdraw its funds from the bank, how are the workers to have any means of livelihood during the period of the strike? How are they going to maintain themselves during the duration of the strike and their activities in connection with the strike?

    In the case of the Naval Base Union, the Government took action to freeze the funds of the union when the strike broke out. All the banks were instructed not to meet any payment on their behalf. As a result of the Government's action, the strikers met with many difficulties. There are other cases. There is the example of the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union. Strike action was taken by some branches of this union. Action was taken by the Government to control their funds. They therefore faced similar difficulties.

    If the Minister is given these dictatorial powers, then the workers will face difficulties in the event of a strike. In fact, these powers will give the Minister many opportunities to break up the legitimate strikes of non-P.A.P. unions. This is my first point.

    The second point I wish to draw your attention to is this. If the workers wish to support the strikes of other unions, that is, by giving material and financial aid, the Government can, by virtue of these provisions in the Bill, abuse their power and freeze the unions' funds. These provisions are meant to prevent certain unions from making use of their funds to assist other unions and other workers who are on strike. Apart from

Column: 820

this point, if such dictatorial powers are given to the Minister, then, in the event of the unions desirous of expanding their activities, and if the Minister does not like certain unions to expand their activities, he will again resort to the powers contained in this Bill to freeze the union funds.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee): On a point of order.

    Mr Speaker: What is the point of order?

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: This is the sixth time that he has mentioned about the Government freezing the funds of the trade unions. He need not have to talk for two hours on just one reason - the freezing of union funds.

    Mr Speaker: There is one clause which deals with the point, and the debate is on that clause. Though he is using the same expression, he is using it in a different context and using different reasons. I rule that he is in order. Please proceed, Mr Chia.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): The Minister can even go to the extent of abusing his powers, contained in this Bill, to threaten certain unions. That is to say, if the Minister does not want certain unions to carry out certain activities in the trade union movement, then he will again take action to freeze the trade union funds. Even when certain unions want to carry out legitimate activities of a cultural nature or, in other respects, to raise the cultural standard of the workers and make use of the union funds for publication purposes, if the P.A.P. desire to stop the activities of these unions, the Minister again can freeze the union funds in order to prevent such activities from being carried out. If these undemocratic powers of a dictatorial nature are given to the Minister, then we can see that the P.A.P. will, by way of this Bill, take action against those non-P.A.P. unions and drive their members over to the other side, namely, the side of the P.A.P.-controlled trade unions. So since the P.A.P. have failed to control the non-P.A.P. unions, they are now resorting to legal

Column: 821

means to further suppress them. The P.A.P. always claim that these unions are indulging in open front Communist activities, and so it is necessary to have this Bill to take action against such unions. But let us look at the facts. This is a document from the Malayan Trades Union Congress. After the Committee came to Singapore for a survey, they came to this conclusion as contained in this document:

    `The Singapore Government always make use of the State machinery and other governmental facilities to help the National Trades Union Congress in Singapore, but neglect those other unions which do not endorse the Government policies.'

    This point has been admitted by the Minister for Labour. In this memorandum the Malayan Trades Union Congress officials continue to say that those trade unions which do not endorse the P.A.P. Government's labour policies always have their leaders intimidated on all sorts of excuses and harassed unnecessarily. Such excuses like anti-national elements, open-front Communist workers and the rest are common expressions used by the Government against them. This is the conclusion arrived at by a third party from an objective point of view. So the so-called "pro-Communist" and "anti-national elements" are but expressions used by the P.A.P. against non-P.A.P.-controlled trade unions if the P.A.P. fail in other ways to deal with them. If the P.A.P. fail to gain their support by legitimate means, they will turn round to brand them as Communist controlled and take action against them. This again is another example to show how one can give a dog a bad name and hang him.

    In this Bill there is also a provision stipulating that the Minister can, in the event of the dissolution of a trade union, direct that the funds be put into the Consolidated Fund of the Government. As we have already said, the funds of a trade union come from the workers by the accumulation of their subscriptions over years. The workers have to work very hard to build up their own funds to safeguard their rights and to enable them to have financial means to carry out their trade union activities.

Column: 822



3.08 p.m.

    

[Mr Deputy Speaker (Dr Fong Kim Heng) in the Chair]


    So how these funds should be used should be decided by the workers themselves. In the event of the dissolution of any union, the members of that union may desire that the funds be used for the welfare of the workers. Therefore, the disposal of such funds should be in accordance with the trade union rules or according to the desire of the members of the dissolved union. It is not proper for the Minister to direct that the funds of that union be put into the Consolidated Fund, thereby depriving the members of that union of their legitimate rights.

    We know that even in the Federation of Malaya or even in England, trade union laws do not have the provision whereby trade union funds can be forcibly put into the Consolidated Fund, which amounts to confiscation in the event of the dissolution of the trade unions.

    In this amending Bill, there is also another provision whereby the Minister's direction that the trade union funds can be put into the Consolidated Fund will have retrospective effect to the 11th of December, 1963. Now this provision is even more unreasonable. According to the present Trade Unions Ordinance, before the Government can freeze the funds of any trade union, an injunction should be applied for in the High Court of Singapore. That is according to the present Trade Unions Ordinance. But in the past, when the Government froze the funds of seven unions of the S.A.T.U. group, the Government used illegal means in freezing their funds. Now the Government are trying to pass a Bill to legalise their illegal acts in the past. For example, recently the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union wished to make use of the union funds in the bank. According to their rules, the funds in the event of the dissolution of the unions should be distributed among the members. Now the Government are trying to race against time to pass this Bill in order to prevent the members of this

Column: 823

union from having a share in the union's funds.

    If any law is to be given retrospective effect, it is improper, and it is even more improper if the P.A.P. should try to make use of this Bill to legalise their illegal acts in the past. Now if legislation is to serve the interests of the P.A.P., then the P.A.P. can make laws and break laws. Then where is democracy? Where is the rule of law? We find, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this Trade Unions (Amendment) Bill is a Bill unprecedented in the history of the trade union movement in Singapore. It is a most undemocratic and dictatorial Bill. If the Government should force through this Bill, then we must condemn them strongly and they should be held responsible for any consequences.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am looking at this Trade Unions (Amendment) Bill as a piece of legislation, and as a piece of legislation, I see three objectionable features of the Bill.

    First of all, the Bill is made retrospective to be applicable to unions which were being closed down before this Bill has been discussed or passed.

    Now, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, any democratic government recognises as a fact that retrospective legislation is a very bad thing. As far as I know, in other democratic countries no government has ever attempted to try to introduce retrospective legislation because, if once the door is opened, we will not know where we stand tomorrow. For instance, today we have freedom of speech in this Assembly, but tomorrow we may not have it here. The speeches we make before such a Bill is passed can also be made effective retrospectively.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the second objectionable feature of this Bill is that the Minister will have the power to seize the funds of a union which he does not approve. Now when a member joins an association, he is like a shareholder buying shares in a public company. May I

Column: 824

state, for instance, a public company is mismanaged or some of its officials have misappropriated the funds or invested them in contravention of the objects of the company. There is nothing to prevent a government in future, based on this precedent, from seizing the funds of that company and putting the, likewise into the Consolidated Fund. Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, very soon we might find many public companies in Singapore being mismanaged - funds being lost, the shareholders lodging complaints with the Minister. [Interruption] I beg your pardon.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Are you worried about your company?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: I have no company. I think the Ministers should investigate how many shares they have in companies they should look after their own shares in companies!

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, it is very unfair to expropriate the funds which rightly belong to the members. When a person becomes a member of a union, or an association or a company, he has complete trust that the articles and rules approved by the Government will be carried out to the letter. Now we have a Bill which will supersede all the previous rules and constitutions approved by the Government, and it will enable the Government to seize control of the funds of the members.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, clause 4 which gives power to the Minister to seize union funds is most objectionable. If the Government have any reason to close down a union - any reason that they can give - the funds should rightly go back to the union members.

    The third objectionable feature, Sir, is that this Bill gives too much power to the Minister. My view is that trade union funds rightly belong to the members. The Registrar of Trade Unions has a legal duty to discharge to see that the funds are not misappropriated or misused by union officials and, for this reason, the best way is to strengthen the Registry of Trade Unions.

Column: 825



    Clause 2 of this Bill enables the Minister to act on information given to the Registrar. The Registrar might have obtained false information. You may remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, that at one time there was some false information about Tommy Koh, a university student who was supposed to be with student pickets, whereas he was actually in Cameron Highands, This sort of thing might happen again. An informer might lodge a complaint with the Registrar of Trade Unions that a meeting is to be held on a certain night and that the union funds will be appropriated. The Minister, acting on this information, will immediately freeze the union funds.

    Now, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, there is sufficient provision in the Penal Code to institute criminal breach of trust proceedings against any union official who misappropriates or misuses union funds.

    Therefore, Sir, I feel that this Trade Unions (Amendment) Bill should not be passed.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Wee Toon Boon): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, a little while ago, the Member for Jurong raised a hue and cry over this Bill. We know why he has made such a strong protest against it. Before the elections, the Barisan had been warned that once merger took place, every step would be taken to check the pro-Communists from manipulating the unions.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, our object is to prevent them from using the unions and other civic organisations for activities which are inconsistent with our national interest. Their allegation that precautionary or whatever steps we take to checkmate them are detrimental to the workers is far from the truth. This is the very Bill that we are introducing in order to protect the interest of the workers.

    I will explain to this House how the pro-Communist elements in the unions manipulate the unions and union funds. I will dwell on this point later. Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, at present the Trade Unions Ordinance has provision to deal with such matters. But this is an old Ordinance which does not

Column: 826

make provision to cope with the situation that we are faced with at the moment - that is, the manipulation of the trade unions by the pro-Communists. If they had been honest and served the interest of the workers, we would not have had to move this Bill to amend the Ordinance this afternoon, in the present Ordinance, there is provision to say that in the event of a union being deregistered by the Registrar or dissolved on its own resolution, the assets and funds of the union should be distributed according to its rules and constitution. If there are people who are genuinely looking after the interest of the workers, the present Ordinance will have sufficed. But, unfortunately, we have an unscrupulous group of persons who are manipulating the unions and they find ways and means to overcome the provisions of the Ordinance, not only to exploit the workers but also their funds - as they say "the sweat and blood of the workers". This is exactly so, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir; we know that that is the workers' money - from the sweat and blood of the workers. And we want to preserve it. That is the present position with regard to the Ordinance.
